{{Infobox Diplomatic Mission | name = Consulate-General of Finland in Saint Petersburg
Генеральное консульство Финляндии в Санкт-Петербурге
Suomen pääkonsulaatti Pietari | image =Consulate_General_of_Finland,_St._Petersburg_20070517.jpg | address = 4 Preobrazhenskaya Square | location = [[Saint Petersburg]] | coordinates = | ambassador = }} The '''Consulate-General of Finland in Saint Petersburg''' is the [[consulate-general]] of the [[Republic of Finland]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russian Federation]]. It is located at 4 Preobrazhenskaya Square ({{lang-ru|Преображенская пл. 4}}) in the [[Tsentralny District, Saint Petersburg|Tsentralny district]] of Saint Petersburg.{{cite web | title = Контакты: Генеральное консульство Финляндии, Санкт-Петербург | publisher = [[Embassy of Finland in Moscow]] | url = http://www.finland.org.ru/public/default.aspx?nodeid=40134&culture=ru-RU&contentlan=15 | accessdate = 2008-07-10 }} == See also == * [[Finland–Russia relations]] * [[Diplomatic missions in Russia]] * [[Anton incident]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{ru icon}} {{fi icon}} {{sv icon}} [http://www.finland.org.ru/public/default.aspx?nodeid=36973&contentlan=15&culture=ru-RU Consulate-General of Finland in Saint Petersburg] {{coord missing|Saint Petersburg}} [[Category:Finland–Russia relations]] [[Category:Diplomatic missions in Saint Petersburg|Finland]] [[Category:Diplomatic missions of Finland|Saint Petersburg]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 2004]] {{russia-stub}} {{finland-stub}} {{russia-struct-stub}}

[[File:Days for Girls logo 2018.png|thumb|right]] '''Days for Girls''' ('''DfG''') is a global movement that prepares and distributes sustainable menstrual health solutions to girls who would otherwise miss school during their monthly periods. The [[nonprofit organization]] was founded in 2008 by American woman '''Celeste Mergens'''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.impactalpha.com/by-women-for-women-the-new-economics-of-menstrual-pads-in-africa-a6e1ace71ba0|title=By women, for women: The new economics of menstrual pads in Africa|last=Thorpe|first=Devin|date=2018-01-09|work=ImpactAlpha|access-date=2018-02-19|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> After visiting an orphanage in [[Nairobi]], Kenya, she discovered that [[menstruation|menstruating]] girls stayed in their dormitories for days, sitting on cardboard to absorb their flow, because they could not afford [[feminine hygiene]] products. Her first response was to organize donations of disposable sanitary pads, but she realized that this was not a sustainable solution — and the girls had no way to dispose of used pads. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ecwid.com/blog/case-study-days-for-girls.html|title=Days for Girls: Improving Girls’ Access to Education, One DfG Kit at a Time|last=Hoffman|first=Ashley|work=Ecwid|access-date=2018-02-20|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> She then developed the idea of creating washable, reusable pads and providing the girls with a personal kit of all they would need to continue their schooling with hygiene and dignity.<ref name="mccray">{{cite web|url=http://www.oprah.com/health/celeste-mergens-days-for-girls|title=Period Drama: Helping Girls Around the World Navigate "That Time of the Month"|last1=Mccray|first1=Linzee Kull|date=January 7, 2014|website=|publisher=Oprah.com|accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref> By 2018, the DfG Kits (designed to last up to three years) and health education programs had reached more than one million girls and women in over 100 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.daysforgirls.org/single-post/2018/01/04/One-Million-And-Counting|title=One Million... And Counting!|last=|first=|date=January 5, 2018|website=Days for Girls International {{!}} Turning Periods Into Pathways|language=en|access-date=18 February 2018}}</ref><ref name="davis">{{cite web|last1=Davis|first1=Tom|title=Bromsgrove School students bake their way to £180 for charity|url=http://www.bromsgroveadvertiser.co.uk/news/15893903.Bromsgrove_School_Students_bake_their_way_to__180_for_charity|publisher=Bromsgrove Advertiser|accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref>
DfG Kits are made by volunteers who either work as "solo sewists" or form "teams," some of which go on to acquire the status of "chapters."<ref name="sewing">{{cite web|title=Sewing DfG kits|url=https://www.daysforgirls.org/chaptersandteams|publisher=Days for Girls|accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref> These groups have formed in many countries, including Australia,<ref name="taree">{{cite news|title=Taree Days for Girls raises funds for hygiene kits|url=http://www.manningrivertimes.com.au/story/5209869/taree-days-for-girls-raises-funds-for-hygiene-kits/|accessdate=16 February 2018|work=Manning River Times|date=6 February 2018}}</ref> Canada,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.westerngazette.ca/culture/days-for-girls-charity-brings-hygiene-kits-to-underprivileged-women/article_2c61813e-0c30-11e8-966e-a3fbaeb353c4.html|title=Days for Girls charity brings hygiene kits to underprivileged women|last=Kim|first=Min Jy|date=February 7, 2018|work=The Gazette • Western University's Student Newspaper|access-date=2018-02-18|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> New Zealand,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/manawatu-standard/news/79998389/charities-seeing-increasing-numbers-of-women-unable-to-pay-for-sanitary-items|title=Charities seeing increasing numbers of women unable to pay for sanitary items|last=Forrester|first=Georgia|date=May 15, 2016|website=Stuff|language=en|access-date=18 February 2018}}</ref> the United Kingdom,<ref name="thompson">{{cite news|url=http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/15969515.Students_praised_for_community_work_in_Malawi/|title=Students praised for community work in Malawi|last1=Thompson|first1=Vicky|date=8 February 2018|work=The Press (York)|accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref> and the United States.<ref name="coronado">{{cite news|title="Days For Girls" Club At Coronado High School|url=http://www.coronadonewsca.com/news/coronado_island_news/days-for-girls-club-at-coronado-high-school/article_33025a7e-0d50-11e8-a803-5f6706fd89ce.html|accessdate=16 February 2018|work=Coronado Eagle and Journal|date=8 February 2018}}</ref> Each kit is in a draw-string bag and includes reusable [[cloth menstrual pad]]s made up of colorful shields and liners; [[panties]]; a [[washcloth]] and soap; [[Zipper storage bag|zip-closure plastic bags]] and other items. The kit enables girls to carry their clean and used pads discreetly and to take care of their own hygiene needs.<ref name="sewing" /> During the distributions, women and girls also receive health education to break stigmas and cultural taboos associated with menstruation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.freep.com/story/life/2016/02/13/days-for-girls-period-menstruation-making-pads-/77450618/|title=Michigan-made sanitary pads keep girls around the world in school|last=Montemurri|first=Patricia|date=13 February 2016|work=Detroit Free Press|access-date=2018-02-19|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
In 2012, Days for Girls International launched an Enterprise Program to help local women establish [[social enterprises]] to make and distribute kits in their own countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.daysforgirls.org/single-post/2018/02/06/Introducing-the-Enterprise-Evaluation-Report|title=Introducing the Enterprise Evaluation Report|last=Mergens|first=Celeste|date=February 7, 2018|website=Days for Girls International {{!}} Turning Periods Into Pathways|language=en|access-date=18 February 2018}}</ref> Close to 70 Days for Girls Enterprises now exist in more than a dozen countries across Africa, Asia, and Latin America.<ref name="enterprise">{{cite web|title=Become an enterprise partner|url=https://www.daysforgirls.org/become-an-enterprise-partner|publisher=Days for Girls|accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref> In select regions and in order to improve sustainability, Days for Girls kits also come with [[menstrual cup]]s, which have a longer use life than washable cloth pads.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.daysforgirls.org/single-post/2018/04/21/Our-Sustainable-Solution|title=Days for Girls International {{!}} Turning Periods Into Pathways|website=Days for Girls International {{!}} Turning Periods Into Pathways|language=en|access-date=2018-04-25}}</ref>
Days for Girls International is headquartered in [[Bellingham, Washington]], United States, and has offices in Ghana, Guatemala, Nepal, and Uganda.<ref name="offices">{{cite web|title=Enterprise Program|url=https://www.daysforgirls.org/enterpriseprogram|publisher=Days for Girls|accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref> The organization's impact and transparency have earned high ratings from [[GuideStar]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.guidestar.org/profile/45-3934671|title=DAYS FOR GIRLS INTERNATIONAL - GuideStar Profile|website=www.guidestar.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-19}}</ref> Celeste Mergens, the organization's founder and CEO, was awarded a Purpose Prize by [[AARP]] in 2017.<ref name="aarp">{{cite web|title=Celeste Mergens|url=https://www.aarp.org/about-aarp/purpose-prize/winners/info-2017/celeste-mergens.html|website=2017 Purpose Prize Winners|publisher=AARP|accessdate=16 February 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|https://www.daysforgirls.org/}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Aa_NyPa2qY4 Celeste Mergens' TEDx talk 2013]

{{Unreferenced BLP|date=November 2018}} '''Dragi Šestić''' (born 14 May 1966) is a [[Bosnia]]n music producer, sound engineer, director of music video clips and record label owner. In 1998 he founded the first Bosnian [[World Music]] band, [[Mostar Sevdah Reunion]]. He rediscovered almost forgotten Gypsy music legends from ex-Yugoslavia [[Šaban Bajramović]] and [[Ljiljana Buttler]]-Petrović and brought them into the spotlight of the international World Music scene.
Šestić was born in [[Mostar]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]].
He worked with the famous maqaam ([[Maqam al-iraqi]]), star and only female master of it{{what?|date=July 2018}} - Farida Ali from Iraq on her album Ishraqaat.
His work involved many of the Balkan stars, including the Queen of Gyspies [[Esma Redžepova]], [[Boban Marković]], [[Naat Veliov]], [[Amira Medunjanin]], [[Fulgerica]], Ljubiša Stojanović ([[Louis (singer)|Louis]]__ and many more. His work can be found on many World Music compilations, but most of it is on his [[record label]] Snail Records, founded in 2002. He lives and works in the [[Netherlands]]. [[File:Dragi Sestic.jpg|thumb|Šestić]]
==Discography as a music producer==
# Mostar Sevdah Reunion: «Mostar Sevdah Reunion» (1999 – World Connection) # Mostar Sevdah Reunion presents Šaban Bajramović: «A Gypsy Legend» (2001 World Connection) # Ljiljana Buttler: «The Mother Of Gypsy Soul» (2002 Snail Records) # Fulgerica and The Mahala Gipsies: «Gypsy Music From The City Of Bucharest» (2002 World Connection) # Mostar Sevdah Reunion: «A Secret Gate» (2003 Snail Records) # Amira: «Rosa» (2004 Snail Records) # Branko Galoić: «Above The Roofs» (2005 Snail Records) # Farida: «Ishraqaat» (2005 Snail Records) # Mostar Sevdah Reunion and Ljiljana Buttler: «The Legends Of Life» (2005 Snail Records) # Mostar Sevdah Reunion and Šaban Bajramović: «Šaban» (2006 Snail Records) # Mostar Sevdah Reunion: «Cafe Sevdah» (2007 Snail Records) # Ljiljana Buttler: «Frozen Roses» (2009 Snail Records) # Sarr e Roma: «Sarayland» (2010 Snail Records) # Louis: «The Last King Of The Balkans» (2011 Snail Records) # Klezmofobia: «Kartushnik» (2012 Tiger Records) # Mostar Sevdah Reunion: «Tales From A Forgotten City» (2013 Snail Records/ World Connection) # Mostar Sevdah Reunion: «Kings Of Sevdah» (2016 Snail Records) # Klapa Reful Split: «Heart Of Dalmatia» (2017 Snail Records) # Mostar Sevdah Reunion presents Sreta: «The Balkan Autumn» (2018 Snail Records) [[File:Mostar Sevdah Reunion and Dragi Sestic.jpg|thumb|Mostar Sevdah Reunion and Dragi Šestić]]
==Awards== * [[Davorin (award)|"Davorin" Bosnian Music Awards]]: Special Award 2002 * "Davorin" Bosnian Music Awards: The Best Ethno Album Of The Year 2003 (for "The Mother of Gypsy Soul: Ljiljana Buttler") * "Davorin" Bosnian Music Awards: The Best Album Of The Year 2004
==Films== * ''Mostar Sevdah Reunion'' by [[Pjer Žalica]] 2000 * ''Sevdah the Bridge that Survived'' by Mira Erdevički 2005<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.eyefortalent.com/ram/MSR%20-%20BBC%20Svedah%20the%20Bridge%20that%20Survived.ram# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2013-07-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120829094236/http://www.eyefortalent.com/ram/MSR%20-%20BBC%20Svedah%20the%20Bridge%20that%20Survived.ram# |archive-date=2012-08-29 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * ''Šaban'' by Miloš Stojanović 2007 * ''Tales from a Forgotten City'' by Amir Grabus 2013
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://www.discogs.com/artist/Dragi+%C5%A0esti%C4%87?anv=Dragi+Sestic&filter_anv=1/ Dragi Šestić at Discogs] *[http://www.snailrecords.nl/ Record label Snail Records] *[http://www.mostarsevdahreunion.com/ Official website of MSR] *[http://www.mostarsevdahreunion.ba/ Mostar Sevdah Reunion – Sluzbena stranica]

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | name = | office = Director General Ghana Prisons Service | order = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | smallimage = <!--If this is specified, "image" should not be.--> | caption = | predecessor = Matilda Baffour Awuah | president = [[John Mahama]] | successor = Patrick Darko Missah | footnotes = | signature = | signature_alt = | party = | birthname = | birth_date = <!--{{birth year and age|1956}} or {{Birth date and age|1977|11|04}}--> | birth_place = [[Ghana]] | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | restingplacecoordinates = | nationality = [[Ghanaian]] | otherparty = <!--For additional political affiliations--> | spouse = | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = Kpando Secondary School, University of Ghana | occupation = Prison Officer | profession = Psychologist | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | blank1 = | data1 = | website = | honorific-prefix = | honorific-suffix = | term_start = | term_end = | religion = | blank2 = | data2 = | blank3 = | data3 = | blank4 = | data4 = | blank5 = | data5 = }}'''Emmanuel Yao Adzator''' is a Ghanaian security expert. He was appointed by [[John Dramani Mahama|President John Dramani Mahama]] as the Director General of the [[Ghana Prisons Service]]. He was succeeded by [[Patrick Darko Missah]] in March 2017.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://233times.com/2017/03/prez-akufo-addo-appoints-dop-patrick-darko-missah-as-prisons-boss/|title=Prez. Akufo-Addo appoints DOP Patrick Darko Missah as prisons boss|work=233times.com|access-date=2018-05-23|language=en}}</ref>
== Education and working life == Emmanuel Adzator had his second cycle education at [[Kpando Secondary School]]. He was admitted to the [[University of Ghana]] and graduated with a Degree in Psychology. He holds a diploma in Human Resource Management from the [[Ghana Institute of Management and Public Administration]]. Emmanuel Adzator was enlisted into the Ghana Prisons Service in April 1989. Whiles at the service he had several training in the corrections system including Correctional Reforms,Re-Entry and Reintegration at Joyfields Training Institute in [[Las Vegas]], [[Navada]] and Advanced Prisons Management, from the Galilee Management Institute, Israel.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.graphic.com.gh/news/general-news/prisons-service-gets-new-director-general.html|title=Prisons Service gets new Director-General|last=Graphic.com.gh|work=Graphic Online|access-date=2018-05-23|language=en-gb}}</ref>
Adzator has headed several prisons in Ghana including [[Nsawam]] Medium Security Prisons and [[Obuasi]] Local Prisons. He became the Ashanti Regional Regional Prisons Commander. He was the General Staff Officer as well as the Criminal Records Officer at the Prisons Headquarters.<ref name=":1" />
== Director General of Ghana Prisons Service == In January 2015 he was promoted from a Deputy Director of Prisons to Director of Prisons along with other superior prison offices.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghana.gov.gh/index.php/media-center/news/130-superior-officers-in-ghana-prisons-service-promoted|title=Superior Officers In Ghana Prisons Service Promoted - Government of Ghana|website=www.ghana.gov.gh|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-05-23}}</ref> In March 2016, then President of Ghana, John Mahama, upon the advise of the Prisons Service Council, appointed him as Acting Director General of the Ghana Prisons Service. Prior to his appointment, he was the Deputy Director General of Prisons in charge of Finance and Administration.<ref name=":1" /> He was succeeded by Patrick Missah in 2017.<ref name=":0" /> == References == {{Reflist}}{{s-start}} {{s-off }} {{s-bef | before = [[Matilda Baffour Awuah]] }} {{s-ttl | title = Director General Ghana Prisons Service | years = 2016 - 2017 }} {{s-aft | after = [[Patrick Darko Missah]] }} {{s-end}}{{Ghana-stub}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Adzator, Emmanuel Yao}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Volta Region]] [[Category:Ghanaian men]] [[Category:Ghana Institute of Management and Public Administration alumni]] [[Category:University of Ghana alumni]]

[[Image:ECAC members.png|thumb|280px|European Civil Aviation Conference]] The '''European Civil Aviation Conference''' ('''ECAC''') or '''Conférence Européenne de l'Aviation Civile''' ('''CEAC''') is an [[intergovernmental organization]] which was established by the [[International Civil Aviation Organization]] ('''ICAO''') and the [[Council of Europe]]. It is located in Neuilly-sur-Seine/Paris in France. Founded in 1955 with 19 member states, the ECAC now totals 44 members, including all 28 [[member states of the European Union|EU]], 31 of the 32 [[European Aviation Safety Agency]] member states, and all 41 [[EUROCONTROL]] member states. ECAC "''promotes the continued development of a safe, efficient and sustainable European air transport system. In doing so, it seeks to ''harmonise civil aviation policies and practices amongst its Member States'' ''and promote understanding on policy matters between its Member States and other parts of the world''".
Its strategic priorities are safety, security and the environment.
ECAC Member States are: Albania, Armenia, Austria, Azerbaijan, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Georgia, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Moldova, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, San Marino, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the Republic of Macedonia, Turkey, Ukraine and United Kingdom.
== Membership == [[File:European aviation organisations members.svg|thumb|300px|Member countries of the ECAC are shown as non-gray. {{legend|#000080|ECAC, [[Eurocontrol]], [[European Common Aviation Area|ECAA]], [[European Union|EU]]}} {{legend|#0000ff|ECAC, [[Eurocontrol]], [[European Common Aviation Area|ECAA]]}} {{legend|#7dffff|ECAC, [[Eurocontrol]]}} {{legend|#ff0101|ECAC, [[European Common Aviation Area|ECAA]]}} {{legend|#ffff7d|ECAC}}]]
ECAC, [[EUROCONTROL]] and [[European Union|EU]] members: * [[Austria]] (1955) * [[Belgium]] (1955) * [[Bulgaria]] (1991) * [[Croatia]] (1992) * [[Cyprus]] (1969) * [[Czech Republic]] (1991) * [[Denmark]] (1955) * [[Estonia]] (1995<ref>https://www.ecac-ceac.org/estonia</ref>) * [[Finland]] (1955) * [[France]] (1955) * [[Germany]] (1955) * [[Greece]] (1955) * [[Hungary]] (1990) * [[Ireland]] (1955) * [[Italy]] (1955) * [[Latvia]] (1993) * [[Lithuania]] (1992) * [[Luxembourg]] (1955) * [[Malta]] (1979) * [[Netherlands]] (1955) * [[Poland]] (1990) * [[Portugal]] (1955) * [[Romania]] (1991) * [[Slovakia]] (1991) * [[Slovenia]] (1992) * [[Spain]] (1955) * [[Sweden]] (1955) * [[United Kingdom]] (1955)
ECAC and [[EUROCONTROL]] members outside the [[European Union|EU]]: * [[Albania]] (1998) * [[Armenia]] (1995) * [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] (2002) * [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] (2005) * [[Macedonia (country)|Macedonia]] (1997) * [[Moldova]] (1996) * [[Monaco]] (1989) * [[Montenegro]] (2008) * [[Norway]] (1955) * [[Serbia]] (2002, as [[Serbia and Montenegro|SiM]]) * [[Switzerland]] (1955) * [[Turkey]] (1955) * [[Ukraine]] (1999)
ECAC-only members: * [[Azerbaijan]] (2002) * [[Iceland]] (1955) * [[San Marino]] (2008)

{{Infobox book | name = Fattypuffs and Thinifers | title_orig = Patapoufs et Filifers | translator = Norman Denny | image = Patapoufs.jpg | caption = Title page of original French edition | author = [[André Maurois]] | illustrator = [[Jean Bruller]] | cover_artist = | country = [[France]] | language = [[French language|French]] | series = | subject = | genre = [[Children's literature]] | publisher = [[The Bodley Head]] | pub_date = 1930 | english_pub_date = 1941 | pages = 96 | media_type = Print ([[hardback]]) | isbn = | oclc = 258165503 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''Fattypuffs and Thinifers''''' ({{ISBN|1-903252-07-5}}) is a 1941 translation of the French [[children's book]] ''Patapoufs et Filifers'' originally written in 1930 by [[André Maurois]]. It concerns the imaginary underground land of the fat and congenial Fattypuffs and the thin and irritable Thinifers, which is visited by the Double brothers, the plump Edmund and the thin Terry. Fattypuffs and Thinifers do not mix, and their respective countries are on the verge of war when Edmund and Terry make their visit.
==Plot summary== Edmund and Terry find the entrance through the Twin Rock, where a long [[escalator]] descends into the bowels of the earth. The underground region is illuminated by large [[balloon]]s filled with a blue, dazzling gas, which float in the underground sky.
At the bottom of the escalator a narrow [[quay]], ''Surface-by-the-Sea'', borders a large gulf. Edmund and Terry are separated here. Edmund is taken to Fattyborough, the capital of the Fattypuff kingdom, on the ship ''Fattiport'', while Terry is ordered to board the steel vessel ''Thiniport'' for Thiniville, capital of the Thinifer Republic.
Edmund soon assumes an important position in the administration of Fattypuff, whose inhabitants are friendly, happy, and who live only for drinking and eating. Everything there is round and cushioned; the architecture is domes and baroque. Terry also rises through the ranks quickly in the land of the Thinifers, [[workaholic]]s all, who scarcely eat, and who rush to and from their country, which is all high, sharp spires and thin railway cars.
For centuries Fattypuffs and Thinifers have been mortal enemies, having fought one another already in the ''War of the Captive Armies''. Their main source of tension lies over ownership of an island in the gulf that separates the countries, and what to call it - the Fattypuffs prefer "Fattyfer," the Thinifers "Thinipuff." Negotiations, in which Edmund and Terry participate, are unsuccessful, and the countries go to war. The Thinifers emerge as the victors, and annex the Fattypuff kingdom.
The consequences of this annexation are unexpected. Many soldiers of the occupying army of the Thinifers begin to marry Fattypuff girls, and return to their homeland with affection for the country that they conquered. The Thinifers begin to adopt Fattypuff cuisine, habits, and attitudes. Consequently, the Thinifer president proclaims that the two peoples form a new nation, the ''United States of the Underground''. King Plumpapuff of the Fattypuffs is made constitutional sovereign, while the Thinifer president is made his [[chancellor]]. All distinctions by weight are abolished. A [[toponymy|toponymic]] compromise is reached: the island of ''Fattyfer-Thinipuff'' is called ''Peachblossom Island''.
Edmund and Terry are allowed to return home, where their father has been looking for them at the base of the Twin Rock. They spent ten months underground, but only an hour has passed on the surface.
==Reception== "To ''[[The Times|the Times]] Literary Supplement'' on 27 December 1941, 'This most amusing fantasy' won pride of place in a review of many juveniles, but purely as comedy..."<ref>{{cite book |title=British Children's Fiction in the Second World War |author=Own Dudley Edwards |year=2007 |publisher=Edinburgh University Press |isbn=978-0-7486-1651-0 |page=47 |url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=C8h87i1OaEgC&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=Fattypuffs+and+Thinifers+Andr%C3%A9+Maurois+review&source=bl&ots=JfFXuvvZ0P&sig=N7cIpwzmK_jo7IVAYwow1zDS3cc&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6TiZVf3BK4Pq8AXko734Dg&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=Fattypuffs%20and%20Thinifers%20Andr%C3%A9%20Maurois%20review&f=false|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref> "From France comes this hilariously nonsensical account of an underground land divided into two countries... The story offers endless possibilities for discussion in the classroom around the subject of politics and international conflicts, but most of all it will be enjoyed for its ingenious plot and zany characterisation. Fritz Wegner's line illustrations play an indispensable part in bringing this story alive."<ref>{{cite book |title=Outside in: children's books in translation |last=Hallford |first=Debhora |first2=Edgardo |last2=Zaghini |year=2005 |publisher=Milet (London) |isbn=978-1-84059-487-4|url=http://www.outsideinworld.org.uk/browse-books.asp?book=215 |accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref> The ''[[Irish Independent]]'' chose ''Fattypuffs and Thinifers'' as one of the top 50 books for children,<ref>{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Top 50 Books for Children|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/books/top-50-books-for-children-30148467.html|accessdate=5 July 2015|work=The Irish Independent |publisher=Independent News & Media| date=2 April 2014}}</ref> while [[Anthea Bell]] chose it as one of "her top 10 favourite books in translation that she would recommend for children."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bell |first1=Anthea |title=Top 10 books for children in translation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/childrens-books-site/2014/mar/27/top-10-childrens-books-in-translation-asterix|accessdate=5 July 2015|work=The Guardian |date=27 March 2014}}</ref>
George Millar wrote: "Technically, Maurois' book belong to the subgenre of [[Hollow Earth]] fantasies, imagining vast countries stretching in enormous caverns right there under our feet, like ''[[Journey to the Center of the Earth]]'' penned by Maurois' illustrious countryman. However, the underground location need not be taken too seriously. Maurois was writing a political fantasy and parable, not a physical one.(...) The code in not really difficult to unravel. Two countries who are hereditary enemies, with divergent cultures and ways of life—one endlessly, pedantically precise and methodical, the other addicted to gourmet food and the good things of life - who can they be but Germans and French.(...) On this basis Maurois can be credited with predicting that there would be a new war and that France would be occupied by Germany; he can also be credited with predicting that there would be ultimately a reconciliation and an end to the prolonged enmity between these two countries - even if the actual EU falls a bit short of the complete unification in the story's happy ending...".<ref>George D. Millar, "Literary and Journalistic Predictions of the Second World War in the 1920's and 1930's" in Margaret Cassiof, ''Round-Up of Critical Essays in 20th Century History and Literature''.</ref>
== See also == * {{Portal-inline|Children's literature}}
==References== {{reflist}} <!-- A musical version was written in the 1980s for performance in a school on England. I found the lyrics to the songs on the Internet a few years ago, but they seem to have disappeared now. If anyone has any knowledge of this musical please post the information here. -->

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=August 2014}} '''Gurzil''' or '''Agurzil''' was a [[war deity]] of the [[Berbers|ancient Berbers]].
In [[traditional Berber religion|ancient Berber religion]], Gurzil was a bull-shaped war god who became identified with the son of [[Amun|Amun (Ammon)]]. He was taken by the Berbers to their battles against the [[Ancient Rome|Romans]].
In the sixth century, [[Corippus]] mentioned that [[Ierna]] -- chief of the Berber tribe known as the [[Laguatan]]s (or ''Luwata'', as they were later known to the [[Arabs]]) -- took his god Gurzil into battle against the [[Byzantine]]s. Ierna was a [[Berbers|Berber]] ruler and a high priest of Gurzil. After the [[Berbers]] were defeated, he fled with the "sacred image" of Gurzil, but was caught and killed and the image destroyed.<ref>John Morris, Arnold Hugh Martin Jones, John Robert: The Prosopography of the Later Roman Empire p. 612</ref> Gurzil was later taken by the Berber queen [[Dihya]] ("the Kahina") into her battles during [[Muslim conquest of the Maghreb]].
A temple among the ruins of [[Gerisa]] in Libya may have been dedicated to Gurzil, and the name of the town itself may even be related to his name.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/16819163/Recherches-Sur-La-Religion-Des-Berberes-1910 |title=Recherches Sur La Religion Des Berberes |trans-title=Research on Berber Religion |author=[[René Basset]] |date=1910 |work=Revue de L’Histoire des Religions |accessdate=October 3, 2011}} {{language icon|fr}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== Bibliography == *[[Yves Modéran|Modéran, Yves]]. (2005). Article 'Kahena (Al-Kâhina)', ''[[Encyclopédie Berbère]]''; vol. 27, p. 4102-4111. (Points out that according to the 6th-century historian [[Procopius]], a Berber king carried an idol of the god Gurzil.)
== See also == * [[Africa (goddess)|Ifri]], war goddess of the [[ancient Berbers]] and origin of the name “Africa”
[[Category:Berber deities]] [[Category:Roman Libya]] [[Category:War gods]]
{{Africa-myth-stub}}

'''Hjálmar''' is 200 meters tall [[Iceland]]ic [[reggae]] band formed in 2004<ref>{{cite web|title=Brilliant but Dull: Hjálmar – Ferdasót|url=http://www.icelandreview.com/icelandreview/reviews/?cat_id=16568&ew_0_a_id=301842|work=icelandreview.com|author=Vatnsdal, Brynjar|date=March 3, 2008|accessdate=December 5, 2009}}</ref> in [[Keflavík]].
==Collaborations== On June 2, 2012, at the concert [http://www.ruv.is/sarpurinn/nr/4625922/ Hljómskálinn á Listahátíð] Hjálmar performed with [[Jimi Tenor]]. When he introduced Tenor, Guðmundur Kristinn Jónsson said that Hjálmar are currently recording an album with him. The album was eventually released in 2013 titled ''Dub of Doom'' and was credited to Jimi Tenor og Hjálmar.
== Members ==
=== Current === *Þorsteinn Einarsson - Guitar and vocals *Sigurður Halldór Guðmundsson - Keyboards and vocals *Guðmundur Kristinn Jónsson - Guitar * Valdimar Kolbeinn Sigurjónsson (2007–present) - Bass * Helgi Svavar Helgason (2007–present) - Percussion
=== Former === * Kristinn Snær Agnarsson (2004-2005) * Micke "PB" Svensson (2005-2007) * Nils Olof Törnqvist (2005-2007) * Petter Winnberg (2004-2007)
== Discography ==
===Albums=== *2004: ''Hljóðlega af stað'' *2005: ''Hjálmar'' *2007: ''Ferðasót'' *2009: ''IV'' *2010: ''Keflavík Kingston'' *2011: ''Órar''
;Collaborations *2013: ''Dub of Doom'' <small>([[Jimi Tenor]] og Hjálmar)</small> *2014: ''[[Legao]]'' <small>([[Erlend Øye]])</small>
;Compilations *2014: ''Skýjaborgin 2004-2014''
===Singles=== *2006: "Saga úr sveitinni" *2008: "Dom hinner aldrig ifatt" <small>(with [[Timbuktu (artist)|Timbuktu]])</small> *2010: "Blómin í brekkunni" *2010: "Gakktu alla leið" *2011: "Messenger of Bad News" <small>(with Jimmy Tenor)</small> *2011: "Í gegnum móðuna" *2011: "Ég teikna stjörnu" *2013: "Skýjaborgin" *2014: "Lof" *2014: "Ferðasót" *2014: "Leiðin okkar allra" *2014: "Tilvonandi vor" *2015: "Undir Fót" *2015: "Hlauptu Hratt" *2016: "Er Hann Birtist" <small>(with Mr. Silla)</small> *2016: "Allt er Eitt" *2017: "Græðgin" *2017: "Glugginn" *2018: "Hættur að anda"

{{multiple issues| {{cleanup|reason=Improve style for general readership; consistent naming and linking; better referencing|date=August 2012}} {{lead rewrite|date=August 2012}} }}
'''ICE Clear Credit LLC''', a Delaware [[limited liability company]], is a Derivatives Clearing Organisation (DCO) previously known as '''ICE Trust US LLC''' which was launched in March 2009.<ref name=OfficeFairTrading>{{cite report |url=http://www.oft.gov.uk/OFTwork/consultations/ice-clear-credit/#.UUPRMBcbKSo |title=ICE Clear Credit LLC application to become a Recognised Overseas Clearing House under s288 & 292 of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 |date=October 2012 |accessdate=March 15, 2013 |publisher=[[Office of Fair Trading]] |location=London, UK }}</ref> ICE offers trade execution and processing for the [[credit derivative]]s markets through Creditex and clearing through ICE Trust™.<ref name=CrudeOil2009>{{cite web |url=https://www.theice.com/publicdocs/ICE_Crude_Oil.pdf |format=PDF |title=ICE Crude Oil |publisher=www.theice.com |year=2009 |accessdate=February 2013}}</ref> ICE Clear Credit LLC operates as a [[central counterparty]] (CCP) and [[Clearing house (finance)|clearinghouse]] for [[credit default swap]] (CDS) transactions conducted by its participants. ICE Clear Credit LLC is a subsidiary of [[IntercontinentalExchange]] (ICE). ICE Clear Credit LLC is a wholly owned subsidiary of ICE US Holding Company LP (ICE LP) which is "organized under the law of the Cayman Islands but has consented to the jurisdiction of United States courts and government agencies with respect to matters arising out of federal banking laws."<ref name=FederalReserveApproval2009 />
==Regulatory Oversight== ICE Trust "is overseen by the Federal Reserve Board and members may include banks or other institutions that fulfill the membership requirements, which include net worth of at least $5 billion as well as a credit rating of A or better." <ref name=OTC2009>{{cite journal |url=https://dx.doi.org/10.3905/JSF.2009.15.2.009 |author1=J Paul Forrester |author2=Joel S Telpner |author3=Edmund Parker |author4=Lawrence Hamilton |author5=Jamila Piracci |title= Proposed Reform of the OTC Derivatives Market: Turning "Weapons" into Plowshares? |journal=The Journal of Structured Finance |date=Summer 2009 |volume=15 |number=2 |pages=9–19 |doi=10.3905/jsf.2009.15.2.009}}</ref> ICE is controlled indirectly by Intercontinental-Exchange, Inc. (ICE) ICE’s wholly owned subsidiary, ICE US Holding Company GP LLC (ICE GP), a Delaware limited liability company, is the general partner of ICE LP. ICE, ICE GP, and. "ICE LP is organized under the law of the Cayman Islands but has consented to the jurisdiction of United States courts and government agencies with respect to matters arising out of federal banking laws."
"[R]egulators increasingly regard clearing houses as central to financial stability (Hosking and Griffiths 2012)." <ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/business/economics/article3637678.ece |title=US exchange warns of redundancies after winning the battle for NYSE |author1=Patrick Hosking |author2=Katherine Griffiths |date=December 21, 2012 |accessdate=March 15, 2013 |publisher=The Times |location=London, UK }}</ref> On July 19, 2012 The [[Financial Stability Oversight Council]] designated ICE Clear Credit LLC as a [[Systemically important financial market utility]] (FMU). <ref group=notes>The [[Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act]] (the Payment, Clearing and Settlement Supervision Act of 2010) mitigate financial risk in the financial system and promoting financial stability by giving the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve authority to set risk management standards for entities that have been designated as [[Systemically Important Financial Market Utilities]] (FMU) by the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC). On July 18, 2012 FSOC designated the eight entities as being systemically important utilities: ICE Clear Credit LLC, The Clearing House Payments Company, L.L.C., on the basis of its role as operator of the Clearing House Interbank Payments System, CLS Bank International, Chicago Mercantile Exchange, Inc., The Depository Trust Company, Fixed Income Clearing Corporation, National Securities Clearing Corporation, The Options Clearing Corporation. It under the FDIC's resolution authority where these entities can be placed into receivership and wound-up by the FDIC rather than reorganizing or liquidating under the supervision of a bankruptcy court.</ref><ref name=USTreasury2012>{{cite web |url=http://www.treasury.gov/initiatives/fsoc/Documents/2012%20Appendix%20A%20Designation%20of%20Systemically%20Important%20Market%20Utilities.pdf |format=PDF |title=Designation of Systemically Important Market Utilities |date= July 19, 2012 |accessdate=March 15, 2013 |publisher=US Treasury Department}}</ref> ICE Clear Credit waived the right to appeal. This subjects this entity to enhanced regulatory oversight. "One of the concerns raised by regulatory bodies is the concentration of CDS trading in only a few dealer institutions in recent years. (Note that the top 10 global banks are involved in 70% of all credit derivatives transactions.) Over time, the use of clearinghouses such as ICE Trust [ICE Clear Credit LLC since July 16, 2011] is expected to reduce the volume of settlement payments among members of the clearinghouse and, in theory, reduce counterparty credit risks that arise under CDS. However, trading CDS through clearinghouses may not effectively address concentration risk given that, at least initially, the clearinghouse members will be the major dealers currently involved in most trades. In order to address counterparty risk, members must provide collateral to ICE Trust [ICE Clear Credit LLC since July 16, 2011] to cover their obligations under cleared CDS. Members must also make initial and ongoing contributions to a guaranty fund that can be used by ICE Trust in the event of a member default (Forrester et al 2009)." <ref name=OTC2009 />
ICE Clear Credit LLC is regulated by the [[Commodity Futures Trading Commission]] (CFTC) as a Derivatives Clearing Organization (DCO) and by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) as a Securities Clearing Agency (SCA).<ref name=OfficeFairTrading />
On July 19, 2012 The [[Financial Stability Oversight Council]] designated ICE Clear Credit LLC as a [[Systemically important financial market utility]] (FMU). <ref group=notes>The [[Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act]] (the Payment, Clearing and Settlement Supervision Act of 2010) mitigate financial risk in the financial system and promoting financial stability by giving the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve authority to set risk management standards for entities that have been designated as [[Systemically Important Financial Market Utilities]] (FMU) by the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC). On July 18, 2012 FSOC designated the eight entities as being systemically important utilities: ICE Clear Credit LLC, The Clearing House Payments Company, L.L.C., on the basis of its role as operator of the Clearing House Interbank Payments System, CLS Bank International, Chicago Mercantile Exchange, Inc., The Depository Trust Company, Fixed Income Clearing Corporation, National Securities Clearing Corporation, The Options Clearing Corporation. It under the FDIC's resolution authority where these entities can be placed into receivership and wound-up by the FDIC rather than reorganizing or liquidating under the supervision of a bankruptcy court.</ref><ref name="USTreasury2012"/> ICE Clear Credit waived the right to appeal. This subjects this entity to enhanced regulatory oversight.
==History== In 2009 ICE Trust became a New York chartered bank for purposes of [[Federal Reserve Act]] <ref name=FederalReserveApproval2009>{{cite web |url=http://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/press/orders/orders20090304a1.pdf |format=PDF |title=Federal Reserve System ICE US Trust LLC New York, New York Order Approving Application for Membership ICE US Trust LLC ("ICE Trust") |accessdate=March 15, 2013 |year=2009}}</ref> and was therefore eligible for membership in the [[Federal Reserve System]].
By 2010, Intercontinental Exchange had cleared more than $10 trillion <ref name=businessweek1> {{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/10_32/b4190056333791.htm |publisher=Bloomberg Business Week |title=ICE's Jeffrey Sprecher: The Sultan of Swaps |author=Chad Terhune |date=July 29, 2010 |accessdate=February 15, 2013 }}</ref> in credit default swaps (CDS) (Terhune Bloomberg Business Week 2010-07-29) through its subsidiaries, ICE Trust CDS (now ICE Clear Credit) in March 2009 and at ICE Clear Europe in July 2009 in New York, launched in 2008, (which also handles soft commodity futures/options) and ICE Clear Europe Limited in London, UK, launched in July 2009, (which also trades in [[energy futures]]) clearing entities for credit default swaps (CDS)(Terhune Bloomberg Business Week 2010-07-29).<ref name=businessweek1 /> <ref group=notes>Intercontinental Exchange's closest rival as credit default swaps (CDS) clearing houses, CME Group (CME) cleared $192 million in comparison to ICE's $10 trillion (Terhune Bloomberg Business Week 2010-07-29).</ref> (CME Group comprises the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the New York Mercantile Exchange and New York Commodities Exchange).<ref name=medill2011>{{cite report |title=Open outcry trading at CME Group fading into obscurity |author=Brendan Bilko |date=March 10, 2011 |url=http://news.medill.northwestern.edu/chicago/news.aspx?id=182756 |accessdate=March 15, 2013 |publisher=Medill Reports |location=Chicago |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130409233644/http://news.medill.northwestern.edu/chicago/news.aspx?id=182756 |archivedate=April 9, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Bloomberg's Terhune (2010) explained how investors seeking high-margin returns use Credit Default Swaps (CDS) to bet against financial instruments owned by other companies and countries. Intercontinental's clearing houses guarantee every transaction between buyer and seller providing a much-needed safety net reducing the impact of a default by spreading the risk. ICE collects on every trade.(Terhune Bloomberg Business Week 2010-07-29).<ref name=businessweek1 /> Brookings senior research fellow, Robert E. Litan, cautioned however, "valuable pricing data will not be fully reported, leaving ICE's institutional partners with a huge informational advantage over other traders. He calls ICE Trust [now ICE Clear Credit] "a derivatives dealers' club" in which members make money at the expense of nonmembers (Terhune citing Litan in Bloomberg Business Week 2010-07-29).<ref name=businessweek1 /> (Litan Derivatives Dealers’ Club 2010)." <ref name=Litan>{{cite web |title=The Derivatives Dealers’ Club and Derivatives Markets Reform: A Guide for Policy Makers, Citizens and Other Interested Parties |author=Robert E. Litan |url=http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/research/files/papers/2010/4/07%20derivatives%20litan/0407_derivatives_litan.pdf |format=PDF |date=April 7, 2010 |publisher=[[Brookings Institution]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528224942/http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/research/files/papers/2010/4/07%20derivatives%20litan/0407_derivatives_litan.pdf |archivedate=May 28, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Actually, Litan conceded that "some limited progress toward central clearing of CDS has been made in recent months, with CDS contracts between dealers now being cleared centrally primarily through one clearinghouse (ICE Trust) [ICE Trust [now ICE Clear Credit] in which the dealers have a significant financial interest (Litan 2010:6)." <ref name=Litan /> However, "as long as ICE Trust [now ICE Clear Credit] has a monopoly in clearing, watch for the dealers to limit the expansion of the products that are centrally cleared, and to create barriers to electronic trading and smaller dealers making competitive markets in cleared products (Litan 2010:8)." <ref name=Litan />
The [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] granted an exemption for IntercontinentalExchange to begin guaranteeing credit-default swaps. The SEC exemption represented the last regulatory approval needed by Atlanta-based Intercontinental. Its larger competitor, [[CME Group|CME Group Inc.]], hasn’t received an SEC exemption, and agency spokesman John Nester said he didn’t know when a decision would be made.
On March 4, 2009, ICE announced that ICE US Trust, LLC (ICE Trust), a New York limited liability trust company, received regulatory approval from the Board of Governors of the [[Federal Reserve System]] <ref name="FederalReserveApproval2009"/> to become a member of the Federal Reserve System and to serve as a [[Clearing house (finance)|clearing house]] and central counterparty for [[credit default swap]] (CDS) transactions, initially for North American CDS indexes and later adding liquid single-name swaps. Now known as ICE Clear Credit LLC it is subject to direct regulation and supervision by the CFTC and the SEC.
Also in March 2009 ICE acquired The Clearing Corporation (TCC). This acquisition provided the risk management framework, operational processing and clearing infrastructure for CDS clearing. ICE paid TCC's cash on hand at the close, $39 million more in cash and gave profit participation of less than 35% of the total to be paid to the 10 initial clearing members of TCC.<ref>{{cite web|title=ICE Clear Credit Regulation and Governance FACT SHEET May 2012|url=https://www.theice.com/publicdocs/clear_credit/ICE_Clear_Credit_Regulation_and_Governance.pdf|accessdate=22 July 2012}}</ref>
ICE Clear Credit LLC received temporary no-action assurances from CFTC to exempt ICE swap market participants from various requirements under the [[Commodity Exchange Act]] (CEA), that would otherwise apply to certain swap transactions as a result [[Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act]]. The exemption was based on the premise that the Dodd-Frank Act reflected an "underlying policy to facilitate the central clearing of CDS transactions to reduce systemic risk in the global financial markets, while also minimizing unnecessary disruption and costs to the markets." <ref name=SEC2011July16>{{cite web |url=https://www.sec.gov/divisions/investment/noaction/2011/iceclearcredit072911-17f6.htm |publisher=US Securities and Exchange Commission |date=July 16, 2011 |title=Investment Company Act of 1940 — Section 17(f) and Rule 17f-6 ICE Clear Credit LLC |accessdate=March 15, 2013}}</ref>
In an article published in the [[New York Times]] (December 11, 2010) Louise Story <ref name=StoryNYT>{{cite news |author=Story, Louise |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/12/business/12advantage.html?hp |title=A Secretive Banking Elite Rules Trading in Derivatives |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 11, 2010 |accessdate=March 15, 2013 }}</ref> argued that members of ICE Clear Credit LLC powerful risk committee drawn from banks like [[Deutsche Bank]], [[JPMorgan Chase]], [[Goldman Sachs]] and [[Morgan Stanley]], "helps oversee trading in derivatives ... [and also] share a common goal: to protect the interests of big banks in the vast market for derivatives, one of the most profitable — and controversial — fields in finance," a system with "costly implications" for customers and smaller banks. "The marketplace as it functions now 'adds up to higher costs to all Americans,' said [[Gary Gensler]], the chairman of the [[Commodity Futures Trading Commission]], which regulates most derivatives. More oversight of the banks in this market is needed, he said."<ref name=StoryNYT /> In the same month, ICE said it was "well positioned" to establish a [[Swap Execution Facility]] (SEF), having met with Commissioner Gensler or his staff four times in the past year to discuss SEF registration. An SEF or multiple SEFs will be the derivatives-trading platform(s) newly required under [[Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act|Dodd-Frank]] financial-markets reform. Other firms said to be looking at becoming SEFs were [[Bloomberg LP]], [[Thomson Financial|Thomson TradeWeb]], Parity Energy,<ref name=CFTC>{{cite web |publisher=CFTC Agenda |url=http://www.cftc.gov/ucm/groups/public/@newsroom/documents/file/agenda033111.pdf |format=PDF |title=Commissioner O’Malia’s SEF Showcase: Current Technology & Market Direction |date=March 31, 2011 |accessdate=}}</ref> and [[MarketAxess]].<ref>Protess, Ben, [https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2010/12/17/swap-execution-facility-the-new-term-on-wall-street/ "Swap Execution Facility: The New Term on Wall Street"], December 17, 2010, 9:47 am. Retrieved 2010-12-22.</ref> In a call with investors on November 1, CEO Sprecher had discussed the company's position in and preparation across its numerous markets, including the prospects for SEFs.<ref>[http://seekingalpha.com/article/233887-intercontinentalexchange-ceo-discusses-q3-2010-results-earnings-call-transcript?source=thestreet "IntercontinentalExchange CEO Discusses Q3 2010 Results - Earnings Call Transcript"], ''[[Seeking Alpha]]'', November 01, 2010. Retrieved 2010-12-22.</ref>
On July 16, 2011, ICE Trust U.S. changed its name to ICE Clear Credit. At that time it registered with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission as a Derivatives Clearing Organization and with the Securities and Exchange Commission as a Securities Clearing Agency.
==See also== *[[IntercontinentalExchange]] *[[Swap Execution Facility]] *[[Credit default swap]] *[[Central Counterparty Clearing]] *[[Clearing house (finance)]] *[[Swap (finance)]] *[[International Swaps and Derivatives Association]] *[[Credit derivatives]]

revision.text:
[[File:Jaap Blokker.jpg|thumb|Jaap Blokker after receiving the Lifetime Achievement Award during the [[ING Group|ING]] Retail Jaarprijs Gala in [[Hilversum]], November 2010]] '''Jacob "Jaap" Blokker''' (5 February 1942 – 5 July 2011) was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] businessman and executive.
Blokker was born in [[Amsterdam]]. From 1976 to 2010 he was general director of [[Blokker Holding]], which operates a series of [[chain stores]] in various countries, the most well known in the Netherlands is [[Blokker (chain store)|Blokker]].<ref name="dutchnews">[http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2011/07/jaap_blokker_of_blokker_retail.php Jaap Blokker, of Blokker retail group, dies], ''[[DutchNews.nl]]'', July 6, 2011</ref> He was also an outspoken critic of the [[euro]] and the effects of [[immigration]] and published his criticism in the Blokker Holding annual reports.<ref name="dutchnews" />
==Death== Blokker died in [[Laren, North Holland|Laren]] aged 69, after a long fight against cancer.<ref>{{nl}} [http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/7867410/__Opvolgers_voor_zieke_Blokker-baas__.html Opvolgers voor zieke Blokker-baas] ''[[De Telegraaf]]'', October 7, 2010</ref><ref>{{nl}} [http://www.standaard.be/artikel/detail.aspx?artikelid=DMF20101007_041 Blokker-baas regelt opvolging] ''[[De Standaard]]'', October 7, 2010</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{nl}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110709195947/http://inmemoriam.blokker.nl/nl/leven_en_werk In Memoriam Jaap Blokker]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Blokker, Jaap}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Dutch businesspeople]] [[Category:Dutch chief executives in the retail industry]] [[Category:Knights of the Order of the Netherlands Lion]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Amsterdam]]
